papers.abstract: Peer matching can enhance the impact of social health technologies. By matching similar peers, online health communities can optimally facilitate social modeling that supports positive health attitudes and moods. However, little work has examined how to operationalize similarities in digital health tools, thus limiting our ability to perform optimal peer matching. To address this gap, we conducted a factorial experiment to examine how three categories of similarity variables (i.e., Demographic, Ability, Experiential) can be used to perform peer matching that supports the social modeling of physical activity. We focus this study on physical activity because it is a health behavior that reduces the risk of chronic diseases. We also prioritized this study for single-caregiver mothers who often face substantial barriers to being active because of immense employment and household responsibilities, especially Black single-caregiver mothers. We recruited 309 single-caregiver mothers (49% Black, 51% white), then we asked them to listen to peer audio storytelling about family physical activity. We randomly matched/mismatched the storyteller's profile using the three categories of similarity variables. Our analyses demonstrated that matching by Demographic variables led to a significantly higher Physical Activity Intention. Furthermore, our subgroup analyses indicated that Black single-caregiver mothers experienced a significant and immediate effect of peer matching in Physical Activity Intention, Self-efficacy, and mood. In contrast, white single-caregiver mothers did not report any significant immediate effect. Collectively, our data suggest that peer matching in health storytelling is potentially beneficial for racially minoritized groups; and that having diverse representations in health technology is required for promoting health equity.

events.Text: To address this gap, we conducted a factorial experiment to examine how three categories of similarity variables (i.e., Demographic, Ability, Experiential) can be used to perform peer matching that supports the social modeling of physical activity. We focus this study on physical activity because it is a health behavior that reduces the risk of chronic diseases. We also prioritized this study for single-caregiver mothers who often face substantial barriers to being active because of immense employment and household responsibilities, especially Black single-caregiver mothers. We recruited 309 single-caregiver mothers (49% Black, 51% white), then we asked them to listen to peer audio storytelling about family physical activity. We randomly matched/mismatched the storyteller's profile using the three categories of similarity variables.

Primary Object: a factorial experiment to examine how three categories of similarity variables affect peer matching in modeling physical activity

Purpose: address gaps between existing studies and our novel approach
Method: randomly matched/mismatched thestellers' profiles using demographic, ability, and experiential variables
Results: We recruited 309 single-caregiver mothers and assessed their responses to peer audio storytelling about family physical activity
Analysis: We evaluated the impact of similarity variables on matching quality and outcome reliability
Challenge: Recruiting sufficient numbers faced difficulties, prompting us to refine our selection criteria
Ethical: Ensured informed consent and data privacy protections were upheld throughout the study
Implications: Establishes new benchmarks for assessing peer influence in physical activity interventions
Contradictions: No contradictions noted with existing literature on peer effects in physical activity

Purpose: To investigate the impact of demographic variables and subgroup effects on physical activity intention through peer matching.
Method: Analyzing data across different groups to compare effectiveness of peer matching strategies.
Results: Our analyses demonstrated that matching by Demographic variables led to a significantly higher Physical Activity Intention.

Furthermore, our subgroup analyses indicated that Black single-caregiver mothers experienced a significant and immediate effect of peer matching in Physical Activity Intention, Self-efficacy, and mood.
In contrast, white single-caregiver mothers did not report any significant immediate effect.
Analysis: The primary analysis focused on comparing physical activity intentions between different demographic groups using peer matching strategies.
Challenge: No specific challenges were mentioned regarding methodology or experimental design.
Ethical: No ethical considerations were highlighted in the provided text.
Implications: Understanding the role of demographics and peer matching in influencing physical activity can inform targeted interventions for specific populations.
Contradictions: There was no mention of contradictions or alternative viewpoints presented in the text.

papers.abstract: A central challenge of social computing research is to enable people to communicate expressively with each other remotely. Augmented reality has great promise for expressive communication since it enables communication beyond texts and photos and towards immersive experiences rendered in recipients' physical environments. Little research, however, has explored AR's potential for everyday interpersonal communication. In this work, we prototype an AR messaging system, ARwand, to understand people's behaviors and perceptions around communicating with friends via AR messaging. We present our findings under four themes observed from a user study with 24 participants, including the types of immersive messages people choose to send to each other, which factors contribute to a sense of immersiveness, and what concerns arise over this new form of messaging. We discuss important implications of our findings on the design of future immersive communication systems.

events.Text: A central challenge of social computing research is to enable people to communicate expressively with each other remotely. Augmented reality has great promise for expressive communication since it enables communication beyond texts and photos and towards immersive experiences rendered in recipients' physical environments. Little research, however, has explored AR's potential for everyday interpersonal communication.

Primary Object: because it allows users to interact beyond text and images toward immersive experiences in their physical environment

Context: However, there remains limited research into AR's role in facilitating daily interpersonal communication among individuals who do not have access to advanced technology.
